subCategories.subCategoryDescription: A unique logical identifier
A unique physical identifier at an external or internal location on the device authorized entities can access
The ability to change the device’s software and firmware configuration settings

ocfMatches.ocfMatchNotes: Prior to operational state, device must be onboarded and configured with either symmetric or asymmetric credentials based on certificates or shared keys  Once operational devices, implement role-based and/or subject based access control for each resource they present to the network.

subCategories.subCategoryDescription: The ability to restrict configuration changes to authorized entities only

ocfMatches.ocfMatchNotes: Prior to operational state, device must be onboarded and configured with either symmetric or asymmetric credentials based on certificates or shared keys  Once operational devices, implement role-based and or subject based access control for each resource they present to the network.
Stored Credentials used to authenticate server to clients.

subCategories.subCategoryDescription: The ability for authorized entities to restore the device to a secure default configuration defined by an authorized entity

ocfMatches.ocfMatchNotes: Describes the Resources and properties that are restored to manufacturer settings.

subCategories.subCategoryDescription: The ability to use accepted cryptographic algorithms (e.g., encryption with authentication, cryptographic hashes, digital signature validation) to prevent the confidentiality and integrity of the device’s stored and transmitted data from being compromised

ocfMatches.ocfMatchNotes: Devices must support TLS/DTLS version 1.2 or greater for all unicast sessions.
Cipher Suites: All heavily reviewed and IETF approved or greater.
Secure storage for credentials is strongly recommended.

subCategories.subCategoryDescription: The ability for authorized entities to configure the cryptography use itself when applicable, such as choosing a key length

The ability for authorized entities to render all data on the device inaccessible by all entities, whether previously authorized or not (e.g., through a wipe of internal storage, destruction of cryptographic keys for encrypted data)

ocfMatches.ocfMatchNotes: Describes the Resources and properties that are restored to manufacturer settings during device reset.

subCategories.subCategoryDescription: The ability to logically or physically disable any local and network interfaces that are not necessary for the core functionality of the device.

ocfMatches.ocfMatchNotes: Describes access control and policy management for both local and network resources.

subCategories.subCategoryDescription: The ability to logically restrict access to each network interface (e.g., device authentication, user authentication)

ocfMatches.ocfMatchNotes: Figure 3 shows security enforcement points

subCategories.subCategoryDescription: The ability to enable, disable, and adjust thresholds for any ability the device might have to lock or disable an account or to delay additional authentication attempts after too many failed authentication attempts.
The ability to update all the device’s software and firmware through remote <e.g., network download> and/or local means (e.g., removable media)

ocfMatches.ocfMatchNotes: The aspects of the software [update] include, but are not limited to, firmware, operating system, networking stack, application code, drivers, etc.

subCategories.subCategoryDescription: The ability to confirm the validity of any update before installing it

ocfMatches.ocfMatchNotes: Process where device validates the software version against a trusted source.

subCategories.subCategoryDescription: The ability to restrict updating actions to authorized entities only

ocfMatches.ocfMatchNotes: A client with the correct authorization can initiate a software update process by setting a software update bit to true or false.  This software update bit enables or disables the update process.

subCategories.subCategoryDescription: The ability to enable or disable updating

ocfMatches.ocfMatchNotes: A client with the correct authorization can initiate a software update process by setting a software update bit to true or false.  This software update bit enables or disables the update process.

subCategories.subCategoryDescription: The ability to set remote update mechanisms to be either automatically or manually initiated for update downloads and installations

ocfMatches.ocfMatchNotes: Describes the use of a combination of software update bits that inform the device to look to a valid update.

subCategories.subCategoryDescription: The ability to enable or disable notification when an update is available and specify who or what is to be notified
The ability to report the device’s cybersecurity state

ocfMatches.ocfMatchNotes: Security Virtual Resources (SVRs) and Access Policy, All SVRs can be accessed by the authorized entity
Describes access control architecture and the access based on state of device.

subCategories.subCategoryDescription: The ability to differentiate between when a device will likely operate as expected from when it may be in a degraded cybersecurity state

ocfMatches.ocfMatchNotes: Device transitions to a self-recovery state SRESET if certain conditions of the device are corrupt.

subCategories.subCategoryDescription: The ability to restrict access to the state indicator so only authorized entities can view it

ocfMatches.ocfMatchNotes: Definition of pstat state resource.  Pstat resource is an SVR and has protected access.

subCategories.subCategoryDescription: The ability to prevent any entities (authorized or unauthorized) from editing the state except for the device’s monitor

ocfMatches.ocfMatchNotes: Definition of pstat state resource.  Pstat resource is an SVR and has protected access.

subCategories.subCategoryDescription: The ability to make the state information available to a service on another device, such as an event/state log server

A unique value associated with the endpoint <or values associated with the functional entities within the endpoint> that exists in a namespace to allow it to be referenced without ambiguity. This value is distinct and distinguishes a device from all other devices.

ocfMatches.ocfMatchNotes: Device IDs shall be unique within the scope of operation of the corresponding OCF Security Domain, and should be universally unique.

subCategories.subCategoryDescription: Protection of device operational and management capabilities by requiring user authentication to read or modify the software, firmware and configuration, including means to ensure device-unique credentials for administrative access, and by protecting access to interfaces.

ocfMatches.ocfMatchNotes: Prior to operational state, device must be onboarded and configured with either symmetric or asymmetric credentials based on certificates or shared keys  Once operational devices implement role-based and/or subject based access control for each resource they present to the network.

subCategories.subCategoryDescription: Protection of the confidentiality and integrity of selected categories of transmitted data via sound cryptographic means, e.g., HMACs, TLS/DTLS, IPsec, or SSH.

ocfMatches.ocfMatchNotes: Data in transit devices must support TLS/DTLS version 1.2 or greater for all unicast sessions.
Cipher Suites: All heavily reviewed and IETF approved or greater.

subCategories.subCategoryDescription: Protection of the confidentiality and integrity of selected categories of stored data via sound cryptographic means.

ocfMatches.ocfMatchNotes: Secure storage for credentials is strongly recommended.

baselineCategories.categoryName: Industry Accepted Protocols are Used for Communications

subCategories.subCategoryDescription: Use of secure, widely used protocols, excluding deprecated and replaced versions and protocols, for communications to and from the device.

ocfMatches.ocfMatchNotes: Shows transport, session and application layer standards.
Devices must support CoAP, and CoAP over DTLS.
Cipher Suites: All heavily reviewed and IETF approved or greater.

subCategories.subCategoryDescription: : Parsing and limiting input data to prevent it from being used directly as code, commands, or other execution flow inputs; and encoding output data in a form appropriate to and limited to its intended usage.

ocfMatches.ocfMatchNotes: Data model enforcement of encoding, type and length.  IoT devices often don't have user input fields but data model enforcement occurs on data inbound and outbound to the system.

subCategories.subCategoryDescription: A limited persistent record in the device of relevant events, secured and available to authorized users.

ocfMatches.ocfMatchNotes: An OCF Platform can generate various kinds of Auditable Events. These Auditable Events can be used for log analysis or for real-time understanding of a system condition.

subCategories.subCategoryDescription: Where cryptography is used, use open, published, proven, and peer-reviewed cryptographic methods with appropriate parameter, algorithm and option selections.

ocfMatches.ocfMatchNotes: Cipher Suites: All heavily reviewed and IETF approved or greater.

subCategories.subCategoryDescription: The ability to verifiably update a device’s software and firmware, post-market, with patches that are authenticated to ensure that they have been deployed by an authorized entity as well as to verify the integrity of the patch.

ocfMatches.ocfMatchNotes: Process where device validates the software version against a trusted source.
A client with the correct authorization can initiate a software update process.

subCategories.subCategoryDescription: The ability for authorized users to securely reconfigure and redeploy a device post-market, especially to return the product to factory defaults or an authorized restore point, and securely remove data collected by the device <that is not essential to its operation>, within a defined period established by the organization.

ocfMatches.ocfMatchNotes: Defines how resources on the device are returned to the manufacturer's default values.

subCategories.subCategoryDescription: Employ a hardware-based immutable root of trust.

ocfMatches.ocfMatchNotes: Hardware Secure storage is recommended for symmetric and asymmetric keys, access credentials and personal private data.

subCategories.subCategoryDescription: Use hardware that incorporates security features to strengthen the protection and integrity of the device

ocfMatches.ocfMatchNotes: Defines levels of Hardware Tamper Protection for cryptographic module.

subCategories.subCategoryDescription: Trust must be established in the boot environment before any trust in any other software or executable program can be claimed.

ocfMatches.ocfMatchNotes: Security Profile Purple: secure boot, hardware backed secure storage

subCategories.subCategoryDescription: Sign code cryptographically to ensure it has not been tampered with after signing it as safe for the device, and implement run-time protection and secure execution monitoring to make sure malicious attacks do not overwrite code after it is loaded.

ocfMatches.ocfMatchNotes: Not In Scope

subCategories.subCategoryDescription: Control the installation of software in operating systems, to prevent unauthenticated software and files from being loaded onto it.

ocfMatches.ocfMatchNotes: A the process whereby the Device validates the software (including firmware, operating system, Device drivers, networking stack, etc.) against a trusted source

subCategories.subCategoryDescription: Enable a system to return to a state that was known to be secure, after a security breach has occurred or if an upgrade has not been successful.

ocfMatches.ocfMatchNotes: Not In Scope

subCategories.subCategoryDescription: Use protocols and mechanisms able to represent and manage trust and trust relationships.

ocfMatches.ocfMatchNotes: Certificate based key management based on public key infrastructure (PKI).

subCategories.subCategoryDescription: Any applicable security features should be enabled by default, and any unused or insecure functionalities should be disabled by default.

ocfMatches.ocfMatchNotes: Describes access control and policy management for both local and network resources.
All implemented discoverable SVRs shall expose a Secure OCF Endpoint
Cipher Suites: All heavily reviewed and IETF approved or greater, no insecure ciphers are enabled.

subCategories.subCategoryDescription: Establish hard to crack, device-individual default passwords.

Certificate Credential Generation: The Certificate Credential will be used by Devices for secure bidirectional communication.
